tit.e: Suikan (everyday garment worn by commoners in ancient Japan)
tit.cmt: Deleted section in brackets - not necessary in the title and is contradicted below, where it mentions it was worn by nobles and the sons of nobles and samurai

sen.j: 水干（すいかん）は、男子の平安装束の一つ。
sen.e: "Suikan" is one of the male Heian Costumes.
"Suikan" was a garment worn by men during the Heian Peroid.
Suikan was a garment worn by men during the Heian period.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをのぞくなどしました。

sen.j: 名称は糊を付けず水をつけて張った簡素な生地を用いるからとも、晴雨両用に便利なため（『続深窓秘抄』）ともいうが、いずれにせよ簡素な服飾であることからの命名のようである。
sen.e: It is said that it was so named because simple fabric put up by water without starching was used, or because it was convenient for both clear and rainy weather ("Zoku Shinsho Hisho (book about names of costumes and memos of the Emperor's wearing)"), but anyway, it seems to have been so named because it was a simple garment.

The name is said to come from the fact that it was made from simple material that was stretched using only water with no starch or, according to the "Zoku Shinsho Hisho (book about names of costumes and memos of the Emperor's clothes)," because it was convenient for both clear and rainy weather, but anyway, it seems to have been so named because it was a simple garment.
sen.cmt: Reworded first part of sentence and changed word order

sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 狩衣に似て盤領（丸えり）の一つ身（背縫いがない）仕立てである。
sen.e: Similar to Kariginu costumes, it was made with agekubi (round collar) and hitotsumi (no back seam).
sen.cmt: 一つ身（背縫いがない）→baby clothesは、分かりづらいと思い、hitotsumi (no back seam)にしました。
sen.e: Similar to Kariginu costumes, it was made with agekubi (round collar) and hitotsumi (seamless back).
Similar to kariginu (informal clothes worn by Court nobles) costumes, it was made with agekubi (round collar) and hitotsumi (seamless back).

sen.j: ただし襟は蜻蛉で止めず、襟の背中心にあたる部分と襟の上前の端につけられた紐で結んで止める。
sen.e: However, the collar was not fastened by Tonbo (dragonfly head shaped hook), but by strings attached to the center of the back of the collar and the end of the uwamae (upper front of clothes) of the collar.
sen.cmt: 蜻蛉→Kagero[帖名はローマ字読みにしました。]はTonbo (dragonfly head shaped hook)に修正しました。(http://members3.jcom.home.ne.jp/pehota02/equipment/clothes/bukesdress02.html)Uwamae (part of the fabric that is wrapped farthest from the skin when wearing a garment that is wrapped in front of one)は、uwamae (upper front of clothes)にしました。
sen.e: However, the collar was not fastened by a tonbo (dragonfly head shaped hook), but by strings attached to the center of the back of the collar and the end of the uwamae (upper front of clothes) of the collar.

However, the collar was not fastened by a tonbo (dragonfly head shaped hook), but by strings attached to the center of the back of the collar and the end of the uwamae (upper front of clothes) of the collar.

sen.j: 平安時代末期の絵巻では、都の庶民の多くが水干を着ている様子が見られる。
sen.e: In Emaki (picture scrolls) from the end of the Heian period shows lots of ordinary people in the capital wearing Suikan.
sen.cmt: 平安時代→Heian eraは、Heian periodに変更。他の次代も同様。
sen.e: Emaki (picture scrolls) from the end of the Heian period show lots of ordinary people in the capital wearing Suikan.
Emaki (picture scrolls) from the end of the Heian period show lots of ordinary people in the capital wearing suikan.

sen.j: 生地は絹や麻 (繊維)など一定しない。
sen.e: The fabric varied from silk to hemp (fiber).
The fabric varied from silk to hemp (fiber).
sen.cmt: Not sure that "(fiber)" is necessary in English
sen.e: The fabric varied from silk to hemp (fiber).

sen.j: 庶民は麻を染めたり摺ったりして色や文様を表した生地を用いていたようであるし、貴族が着る場合は高級な生地を多用した。
sen.e: It seems that ordinary people used fabric with coloring or pattern by dyeing or coloring hemp, and the aristocracy often used expensive fabric when they wore.
It seems that ordinary people used hemp, colored or patterned by dyeing or printing, and the aristocracy often used expensive fabric.

sen.j: また鎌倉時代から室町時代には公武の童形（元服前）の礼装として多用される。
sen.e: From the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, it was often used as a formal wear for dogyo (boys before coming-of-age) of court nobles and Samurai.
sen.cmt: 童形（元服前）→dogyo (boy before grown man)を、dogyo (boy before coming-of-age)に。
sen.e: From the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, suikan were often used as formal wear for the sons of court nobles and samurai before they came of age.
sen.cmt: Changed "it" to "Suikan"Reworded to remove Japanese term - I think the English gets the meaning across
sen.e: From the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period, suikan were often used as formal wear for the sons of court nobles and samurai before they came of age.

sen.j: 白拍子の水干も、童形水干と発想がつながるものであろう。
sen.e: Suikan for shira byoshi (chanting and dancing) must be related to the idea of Suikan for dogyo.
sen.cmt: 白拍子→shira byoshi (chanting and dance)を、shira byoshi (chanting and dancing)にさせてもらいました。童形水干は、童形も水干も既出の言葉なので、そのまま使用。
sen.e: This use of suikan probably influenced their use by female shira byoshi dancers.
This use of suikan probably influenced their use by a women who play Shirabyoshi (Japanese traditional dance).

sen.j: 着装は通常袴に籠めて着装するが、寺院の稚児などには掛水干といって狩衣のように袴の上に着て帯を締める着装も行われた。
sen.e: As for dressing, it was usually worn by putting inside hakama (Japanese male ceremonial skirt), but there was another way of dressing called Kake suikan (cover-up suikan), that was worn by wearing over hakama like Kariginu, tightening an obi sash by a page of a temple.
sen.cmt: 寺院の稚児→bronk of a templeは、page of a templeに変更してみました。
sen.e: Suikan were usually worn inside hakama (Japanese male ceremonial skirt), but in the style known as kake suikan (covering suikan), worn by temple page boys, they were worn over hakama, like Kariginu, and tied with an obi sash.

Suikan were usually worn inside hakama (Japanese male ceremonial skirt), but in the style known as kake suikan (covering suikan), worn by temple page boys, they were worn over hakama, like Kariginu, and tied with an obi sash.

sen.j: 襟の紐は普通に結ぶほか、襟を折って胸前で結ぶなどさまざまな着方が行われ、近世武家故実においては諸説がおこなわれた。
sen.e: The strings of the collar were knotted normally, or knotted in front of the front by folding the collar, which was another way of wearing, and recent times' practices or customs of samurai families had various other ways.
The strings of the collar were knotted normally, or knotted in front of the chest by folding the collar, and samurai families at the end of the feudal era had various other ways.
sen.cmt: Reworded for clarity - I think "近世" here refers to the period before the Meiji restoration

sen.j: 貴族の着装の機会は、院政から鎌倉時代に、太上天皇が宇治などの遠所に御幸するときに供奉の貴族が用いた例などを挙げることができ、鎌倉時代後期の「春日権現験記絵」や「なよ竹物語絵巻」では貴族が家庭内での略装として黄色い無文水干を用いている図が見られる。
sen.e: As for dressing opportunities of the aristocracy, for example, the aristocrats accompanying Daijo-tenno (retired Emperor) when having Gokyo (Emperor's going out) to a distant place such as Uji, wore it from the cloister government period to the Kamakura period, and 'Kasuga Gongen Kenkie (picture scrolls of origins of Kasuga Shrine)' and 'Nayotake Monogatari Emaki (picture scrolls of Tales of Nayotake)' in the late Kamakura period have pictures that aristocrats wore yellow mumon suikan (suikan without decoration) as an informal wear at home.

From the cloistered government period to the Kamakura period, the aristocracy wore suika when accompanying the retired Emperor on long journeys to places such as Uji, and the 'Kasuga Gongen Kenkie (picture scrolls of the origins of Kasuga Shrine)' and 'Nayotake Monogatari Emaki (picture scrolls of the Tales of Nayotake)' from the late Kamakura period have pictures of aristocrats waering yellow mumon suikan (unpatterned suikan) as informal wear at home.

sen.cmt: クォーテーションの位置などをを変えました。

sen.j: しかし、室町時代に入ると貴族にも直垂が広まり、武家も直垂を多用したので、童水干などを除いて着装機会は減少した。
sen.e: However, in the Muromachi period, Hitatare costumes prevailed also among the aristocracy, and samurai families often used Hitatare costumes as well, so its dressing opportunities decreased except warabe suikan (suikan for boys before coming-of-age).

However, in the Muromachi period, hitatare ceremonial robes became popular among the aristocracy and the samurai families, so opportunities for wearing suinkan decreased, except by boys before they came of age.

sen.j: 近世では新井白石像に水干着装図が見られるなどしばしば用いられたが、幕府の服飾制度からは脱落している。
sen.e: In the recent times, it was often seen as in the image of Hakuseki ARAI wearing Suikan, but it was left out from the clothing system of the Shogunate.
sen.cmt: 新井白石像→statue of Hakuseki ARAIは、この像はimageと解釈しました。幕府→Shogunate/bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)は、ここではShogunateだけでよいと判断しました。
sen.e: Nineteenth century images of Hakuseki ARAI show him wearing suikan, although it was not included in the Shogunate's clothing system.

sen.j: 公家社会では、白生平絹や白精好地に白い紐、黒い袖括りと菊綴をつけ、同じ生地で黒い菊綴を着けた「長絹」という水干が童形の礼装として多用された。
sen.e: In the society of court nobles, Suikan called 'choken (outer garment with wide sleeves)' which had Shiroki Heiken (undyed white plain weave silk) or Shiro Seigoji (thick and white plain weave silk texture) with white strings, black sodekukuri (straps to turn up the cuffs), kikutoji (tassels) and black kikutoji with the same texture, was often used as a formal wear for dogyo (boy before coming-of-age).
sen.cmt: 白生平絹→Shiroki Heiken (white plain weave silk, not dyed)をShiroki Heikan (undyed white plain weave silk)にしました。菊綴→Kikutoji (tassels stitched on hitatare (the standard day wear for members of the military class)は、kikutoji (tassels)に。

sen.j: 戦後は女子神職の略装として掛水干が用いられたが、平成に入って女子神職の装束が新たに制定されて、神社本庁の服制からも脱落することとなった。
sen.e: After the war, Kake suikan was used as demitoilet of female Shinto Priests, but in the Heisei period, the costume of female Shinto Priests were newly established, which made it left out also from the dress code system of the Association of Shinto Shrine.
